00037 // Execute linear motion in absolute millimeter coordinates. Feed rate given in millimeters/second
00038 // unless invert_feed_rate is true. Then the feed_rate means that the motion should be completed in
00039 // (1 minute)/feed_rate time.
00040 // NOTE: This is the primary gateway to the grbl planner. All line motions, including arc line 
00041 // segments, must pass through this routine before being passed to the planner. The seperation of
00042 // mc_line and plan_buffer_line is done primarily to place non-planner-type functions from being
00043 // in the planner and to let backlash compensation or canned cycle integration simple and direct.
00044 #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00045 void mc_line(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, int32_t line_number)
00046 #else
00047 void mc_line(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate)
00048 #endif
00049 {
00050   // If enabled, check for soft limit violations. Placed here all line motions are picked up
00051   // from everywhere in Grbl.
00052   if (bit_istrue(settings.flags,BITFLAG_SOFT_LIMIT_ENABLE)) { limits_soft_check(target); }    
00053       
00054   // If in check gcode mode, prevent motion by blocking planner. Soft limits still work.
00055   if (sys.state == STATE_CHECK_MODE) { return; }
00056     
00057   // NOTE: Backlash compensation may be installed here. It will need direction info to track when
00058   // to insert a backlash line motion(s) before the intended line motion and will require its own
00059   // plan_check_full_buffer() and check for system abort loop. Also for position reporting 
00060   // backlash steps will need to be also tracked, which will need to be kept at a system level.
00061   // There are likely some other things that will need to be tracked as well. However, we feel
00062   // that backlash compensation should NOT be handled by Grbl itself, because there are a myriad
00063   // of ways to implement it and can be effective or ineffective for different CNC machines. This
00064   // would be better handled by the interface as a post-processor task, where the original g-code
00065   // is translated and inserts backlash motions that best suits the machine. 
00066   // NOTE: Perhaps as a middle-ground, all that needs to be sent is a flag or special command that
00067   // indicates to Grbl what is a backlash compensation motion, so that Grbl executes the move but
00068   // doesn't update the machine position values. Since the position values used by the g-code
00069   // parser and planner are separate from the system machine positions, this is doable.
00070 
00071   // If the buffer is full: good! That means we are well ahead of the robot. 
00072   // Remain in this loop until there is room in the buffer.
00073   do {
00074     protocol_execute_runtime(); // Check for any run-time commands
00075     if (sys.abort) { return; } // Bail, if system abort.
00076     if ( plan_check_full_buffer() ) { protocol_auto_cycle_start(); } // Auto-cycle start when buffer is full.
00077     else { break; }
00078   } while (1);
00079 
00080   #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00081   plan_buffer_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate, line_number);
00082   #else
00083   plan_buffer_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00084   #endif
00085   
00086   // If idle, indicate to the system there is now a planned block in the buffer ready to cycle 
00087   // start. Otherwise ignore and continue on.
00088   if (!sys.state) { sys.state = STATE_QUEUED; }
00089 }
00090 
00091 
00092 // Execute an arc in offset mode format. position == current xyz, target == target xyz, 
00093 // offset == offset from current xyz, axis_XXX defines circle plane in tool space, axis_linear is
00094 // the direction of helical travel, radius == circle radius, isclockwise boolean. Used
00095 // for vector transformation direction.
00096 // The arc is approximated by generating a huge number of tiny, linear segments. The chordal tolerance
00097 // of each segment is configured in settings.arc_tolerance, which is defined to be the maximum normal
00098 // distance from segment to the circle when the end points both lie on the circle.
00099 #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00100 void mc_arc(float *position, float *target, float *offset, uint8_t axis_0, uint8_t axis_1, 
00101   uint8_t axis_linear, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, float radius, uint8_t isclockwise, int32_t line_number)
00102 #else
00103 void mc_arc(float *position, float *target, float *offset, uint8_t axis_0, uint8_t axis_1, 
00104   uint8_t axis_linear, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, float radius, uint8_t isclockwise)
00105 #endif
00106 {      
00107   float center_axis0 = position[axis_0] + offset[axis_0];
00108   float center_axis1 = position[axis_1] + offset[axis_1];
00109   float linear_travel = target[axis_linear] - position[axis_linear];
00110   float r_axis0 = -offset[axis_0];  // Radius vector from center to current location
00111   float r_axis1 = -offset[axis_1];
00112   float rt_axis0 = target[axis_0] - center_axis0;
00113   float rt_axis1 = target[axis_1] - center_axis1;
00114   
00115   // CCW angle between position and target from circle center. Only one atan2() trig computation required.
00116   float angular_travel = atan2(r_axis0*rt_axis1-r_axis1*rt_axis0, r_axis0*rt_axis0+r_axis1*rt_axis1);
00117   if (isclockwise) { // Correct atan2 output per direction
00118     if (angular_travel >= 0) { angular_travel -= 2*M_PI; }
00119   } else {
00120     if (angular_travel <= 0) { angular_travel += 2*M_PI; }
00121   }
00122 
00123   // NOTE: Segment end points are on the arc, which can lead to the arc diameter being smaller by up to
00124   // (2x) settings.arc_tolerance. For 99% of users, this is just fine. If a different arc segment fit
00125   // is desired, i.e. least-squares, midpoint on arc, just change the mm_per_arc_segment calculation.
00126   // Computes: mm_per_arc_segment = sqrt(4*arc_tolerance*(2*radius-arc_tolerance)),
00127   //           segments = millimeters_of_travel/mm_per_arc_segment
00128   float millimeters_of_travel = hypot(angular_travel*radius, fabs(linear_travel));
00129   uint16_t segments = floor(0.5*millimeters_of_travel/
00130                           sqrt(settings.arc_tolerance*(2*radius - settings.arc_tolerance)) );
00131   
00132   if (segments) { 
00133     // Multiply inverse feed_rate to compensate for the fact that this movement is approximated
00134     // by a number of discrete segments. The inverse feed_rate should be correct for the sum of 
00135     // all segments.
00136     if (invert_feed_rate) { feed_rate *= segments; }
00137    
00138     float theta_per_segment = angular_travel/segments;
00139     float linear_per_segment = linear_travel/segments;
00140 
00141     /* Vector rotation by transformation matrix: r is the original vector, r_T is the rotated vector,
00142        and phi is the angle of rotation. Solution approach by Jens Geisler.
00143            r_T = [cos(phi) -sin(phi);
00144                   sin(phi)  cos(phi] * r ;
00145        
00146        For arc generation, the center of the circle is the axis of rotation and the radius vector is 
00147        defined from the circle center to the initial position. Each line segment is formed by successive
00148        vector rotations. Single precision values can accumulate error greater than tool precision in some
00149        cases. So, exact arc path correction is implemented. This approach avoids the problem of too many very
00150        expensive trig operations [sin(),cos(),tan()] which can take 100-200 usec each to compute.
00151   
00152        Small angle approximation may be used to reduce computation overhead further. A third-order approximation
00153        (second order sin() has too much error) holds for nearly all CNC applications, except for possibly very
00154        small radii (~0.5mm). In other words, theta_per_segment would need to be greater than 0.25 rad(14 deg) 
00155        and N_ARC_CORRECTION would need to be large to cause an appreciable drift error (>5% of radius, for very
00156        small radii, 5% of 0.5mm is very, very small). N_ARC_CORRECTION~=20 should be more than small enough to 
00157        correct for numerical drift error. Also decreasing the tolerance will improve the approximation too.
00158        
00159        This approximation also allows mc_arc to immediately insert a line segment into the planner 
00160        without the initial overhead of computing cos() or sin(). By the time the arc needs to be applied
00161        a correction, the planner should have caught up to the lag caused by the initial mc_arc overhead. 
00162        This is important when there are successive arc motions. 
00163     */
00164     // Computes: cos_T = 1 - theta_per_segment^2/2, sin_T = theta_per_segment - theta_per_segment^3/6) in ~52usec
00165     float cos_T = 2.0 - theta_per_segment*theta_per_segment;
00166     float sin_T = theta_per_segment*0.16666667*(cos_T + 4.0);
00167     cos_T *= 0.5;
00168 
00169     float arc_target[N_AXIS];
00170     float sin_Ti;
00171     float cos_Ti;
00172     float r_axisi;
00173     uint16_t i;
00174     uint8_t count = 0;
00175   
00176     // Initialize the linear axis
00177     arc_target[axis_linear] = position[axis_linear];
00178   
00179     for (i = 1; i<segments; i++) { // Increment (segments-1)
00180       
00181       if (count < N_ARC_CORRECTION) {
00182         // Apply vector rotation matrix. ~40 usec
00183         r_axisi = r_axis0*sin_T + r_axis1*cos_T;
00184         r_axis0 = r_axis0*cos_T - r_axis1*sin_T;
00185         r_axis1 = r_axisi;
00186         count++;
00187       } else {
00188         // Arc correction to radius vector. Computed only every N_ARC_CORRECTION increments. ~375 usec
00189         // Compute exact location by applying transformation matrix from initial radius vector(=-offset).
00190         cos_Ti = cos(i*theta_per_segment);
00191         sin_Ti = sin(i*theta_per_segment);
00192         r_axis0 = -offset[axis_0]*cos_Ti + offset[axis_1]*sin_Ti;
00193         r_axis1 = -offset[axis_0]*sin_Ti - offset[axis_1]*cos_Ti;
00194         count = 0;
00195       }
00196   
00197       // Update arc_target location
00198       arc_target[axis_0] = center_axis0 + r_axis0;
00199       arc_target[axis_1] = center_axis1 + r_axis1;
00200       arc_target[axis_linear] += linear_per_segment;
00201       
00202       #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00203       mc_line(arc_target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate, line_number);
00204       #else
00205       mc_line(arc_target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00206       #endif
00207       
00208       // Bail mid-circle on system abort. Runtime command check already performed by mc_line.
00209       if (sys.abort) { return; }
00210     }
00211   }
00212   // Ensure last segment arrives at target location.
00213   #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00214   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate, line_number);
00215   #else
00216   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00217   #endif
00218 }
00219

00221 // Execute dwell in seconds.
00222 void mc_dwell(float seconds) 
00223 {
00224    uint16_t i = floor(1000/DWELL_TIME_STEP*seconds);
00225    protocol_buffer_synchronize();
00226    delay_ms(floor(1000*seconds-i*DWELL_TIME_STEP)); // Delay millisecond remainder.
00227    while (i-- > 0) {
00228      // NOTE: Check and execute runtime commands during dwell every <= DWELL_TIME_STEP milliseconds.
00229      protocol_execute_runtime();
00230      if (sys.abort) { return; }
00231      _delay_ms(DWELL_TIME_STEP); // Delay DWELL_TIME_STEP increment
00232    }
00233 }

00236 // Perform homing cycle to locate and set machine zero. Only '$H' executes this command.
00237 // NOTE: There should be no motions in the buffer and Grbl must be in an idle state before
00238 // executing the homing cycle. This prevents incorrect buffered plans after homing.
00239 void mc_homing_cycle()
00240 {
00241   sys.state = STATE_HOMING; // Set system state variable
00242   limits_disable(); // Disable hard limits pin change register for cycle duration
00243     
00244   // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00245   // Perform homing routine. NOTE: Special motion case. Only system reset works.
00246   
00247   // Search to engage all axes limit switches at faster homing seek rate.
00248   limits_go_home(HOMING_CYCLE_0);  // Homing cycle 0
00249   #ifdef HOMING_CYCLE_1
00250     limits_go_home(HOMING_CYCLE_1);  // Homing cycle 1
00251   #endif
00252   #ifdef HOMING_CYCLE_2
00253     limits_go_home(HOMING_CYCLE_2);  // Homing cycle 2
00254   #endif
00255     
00256   protocol_execute_runtime(); // Check for reset and set system abort.
00257   if (sys.abort) { return; } // Did not complete. Alarm state set by mc_alarm.
00258 
00259   // Homing cycle complete! Setup system for normal operation.
00260   // -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00261 
00262   // Gcode parser position was circumvented by the limits_go_home() routine, so sync position now.
00263   gc_sync_position();
00264   
00265   // Set idle state after homing completes and before returning to main program.  
00266   sys.state = STATE_IDLE;
00267   st_go_idle(); // Set idle state after homing completes
00268 
00269   // If hard limits feature enabled, re-enable hard limits pin change register after homing cycle.
00270   limits_init();
00271 }
00272 
00273 
00274 // Perform tool length probe cycle. Requires probe switch.
00275 // NOTE: Upon probe failure, the program will be stopped and placed into ALARM state.
00276 #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00277 void mc_probe_cycle(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate, int32_t line_number)
00278 #else
00279 void mc_probe_cycle(float *target, float feed_rate, uint8_t invert_feed_rate)
00280 #endif
00281 {
00282   if (sys.state != STATE_CYCLE) protocol_auto_cycle_start();
00283   protocol_buffer_synchronize(); // Finish all queued commands
00284   if (sys.abort) { return; } // Return if system reset has been issued.
00285 
00286   // Perform probing cycle. Planner buffer should be empty at this point.
00287   #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00288   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate, line_number);
00289   #else
00290   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate);
00291   #endif
00292 
00293   //TODO - make sure the probe isn't already closed
00294   sys.probe_state = PROBE_ACTIVE;
00295 
00296   sys.execute |= EXEC_CYCLE_START;
00297   do {
00298     protocol_execute_runtime(); 
00299     if (sys.abort) { return; } // Check for system abort
00300   } while ((sys.state != STATE_IDLE) && (sys.state != STATE_QUEUED));
00301 
00302   if (sys.probe_state == PROBE_ACTIVE) { sys.execute |= EXEC_CRIT_EVENT; }
00303   protocol_execute_runtime();   // Check and execute run-time commands
00304   if (sys.abort) { return; } // Check for system abort
00305 
00306   //Prep the new target based on the position that the probe triggered
00307   uint8_t i;
00308   for(i=0; i<N_AXIS; ++i){
00309     target[i] = (float)sys.probe_position[i]/settings.steps_per_mm[i];
00310   }
00311 
00312   protocol_execute_runtime();
00313 
00314   st_reset(); // Immediately force kill steppers and reset step segment buffer.
00315   plan_reset(); // Reset planner buffer. Zero planner positions. Ensure homing motion is cleared.
00316   plan_sync_position(); // Sync planner position to current machine position for pull-off move.
00317 
00318   #ifdef USE_LINE_NUMBERS
00319   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate, line_number); // Bypass mc_line(). Directly plan homing motion.
00320   #else
00321   mc_line(target, feed_rate, invert_feed_rate); // Bypass mc_line(). Directly plan homing motion.
00322   #endif
00323 
00324   sys.execute |= EXEC_CYCLE_START;
00325   protocol_buffer_synchronize(); // Complete pull-off motion.
00326   if (sys.abort) { return; } // Did not complete. Alarm state set by mc_alarm.
00327 
00328   // Gcode parser position was circumvented by the this routine, so sync position now.
00329   gc_sync_position();
00330 
00331   //TODO - ouput a mandatory status update with the probe position.  What if another was recently sent?
00332   report_probe_parameters();
00333 }
00334 
00335 
00336 // Method to ready the system to reset by setting the runtime reset command and killing any
00337 // active processes in the system. This also checks if a system reset is issued while Grbl
00338 // is in a motion state. If so, kills the steppers and sets the system alarm to flag position
00339 // lost, since there was an abrupt uncontrolled deceleration. Called at an interrupt level by
00340 // runtime abort command and hard limits. So, keep to a minimum.
00341 void mc_reset()
00342 {
00343   // Only this function can set the system reset. Helps prevent multiple kill calls.
00344   if (bit_isfalse(sys.execute, EXEC_RESET)) {
00345     sys.execute |= EXEC_RESET;
00346 
00347     // Kill spindle and coolant.   
00348     spindle_stop();
00349     coolant_stop();
00350 
00351     // Kill steppers only if in any motion state, i.e. cycle, feed hold, homing, or jogging
00352     // NOTE: If steppers are kept enabled via the step idle delay setting, this also keeps
00353     // the steppers enabled by avoiding the go_idle call altogether, unless the motion state is
00354     // violated, by which, all bets are off.
00355     if (sys.state & (STATE_CYCLE | STATE_HOLD | STATE_HOMING)) {
00356       sys.execute |= EXEC_ALARM; // Flag main program to execute alarm state.
00357       st_go_idle(); // Force kill steppers. Position has likely been lost.
00358     }
00359   }
00360 }
